Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Politics and Belief of Religious Conversion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
New School University doctoral student Diego Caguenas, supervised by Dr. Ann Stoler, will undertake anthropological research on the phenomenon of indigenous politicization in Latin America. The lens through which he will view these changes is the movement away from world religions introduced by colonial powers and back to revived local religions. Such movements in Latin America echo a broader rejection of secularism in many parts of the contemporary world, which makes them of social scientific as well as social policy interest.

The research will be carried out in Tierradentro, Colombia, where a 1994 landslide prompted the indigenous Nasa people to return to traditional religious practices. The researcher will investigate redefinitions of personhood that characterize this radical Nasa revivalism called Cosmovision. Nasa activists have been working to recast Nasa spirituality as an autonomous belief system, which precludes the melding of native and Christian philosophies. Their aim is to produce a "true Nasa" who would be attuned to a broader spiritual universe and set of native beliefs. The researcher hypothesizes that local actors take up conversion to Catholicism or to Cosmovision as strategies of personal re-identification in an increasingly secular society as part of the active formation of an ethnic self-awareness. Research methods will include long-term participant observation, structured and semi-structured interviewing, and analysis of archival documents.

The findings of this research will contribute not only to the study of an underrepresented geographical area, but will also address a broader topic: the historic and ongoing impact of Catholic evangelization on indigenous beliefs and political activism. The research is important because it will contribute to theoretical understanding of a worldwide trend away from secularism. Funding this research also supports the education of a social scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research turns around the question of belief. Usually, belief is seen as opposed to rationality and/or as belonging to religious experience. As such, it is often disregarded as defective knowledge that could be perfected by means of empiric evidence. However, as I have learned while doing fieldwork in Tierradentro, southwest Colombia these last 12 months, belief is a much more complex and elusive object of inquiry. To begin with, given that the vast majority of the knowledge we hold comes to us second-hand (if not third- or fourth-hand), it is obvious that empiric evidence is not the token of certitude. How do we know that what we know is true? The lines separating “grounded” knowledge from belief become blurry.

Working on the ground with the people of Tierradentro, however, soon made me realize this is not the best way to tackle the question of belief. To be brief, the distinction between knowledge and belief grounded on empirical evidence or firsthand experience supposes a mentalist view of our understanding of the world, i.e. it supposes that in order to comprehend the world we, somehow, represent it in our heads. Thus, the issue of truth would be one of comparison between our mental representations and the world outside. But how can we be sure that the comparison is sound? If one were to follow this path of inquiry, the questions will not only multiply, but also lead one astray, especially because down this path one leaves behind the social world, which is the natural environment of belief.

What I propose in my research is that belief should be understood as a relational state of affairs. Belief, rather than a mental phenomenon, is the stance through which we actively engage with the world and with other people. Therefore, it is also wrong to think that belief is mostly religious belief. In fact, what I found in Tierradentro is that belief is most active there were our most pressing worries are. When I first arrived to this area of Colombia, I was trying to understand the struggle between two different religious worldviews. On the one hand, I was interested in how Catholicism was either resisted or embraced by the indigenous population of Tierradentro (the most important group being the Nasa), and how much did they know about “cosmovision”, a cultural project orchestrated by indigenous activists, whose aim is to rearticulate and recast Nasa spirituality as an autonomous belief system, independent from Catholic doctrine and the state’s secular politics. Their aim is to produce a “true Nasa” who would be attuned to a broader spiritual universe and set of native beliefs. However, what I found is that neither Catholicism nor cosmovision were much discussed. In fact, many haven’t even heard of the latter.

In Belalcázar, the town where I spent most of my fieldwork time, there were other causes for worry, the most salient of which being the possible relocation of the town. Belalcázar is located near a volcano that has been very active since the early 1990s. In 1994 an earthquake related to the volcano’s activity caused an enormous avalanche that killed around 1,000 people, and completely destroyed four towns. Belalcázar was severely hit and lost near half of its urban area. Since then, other avalanches have made living in Belalcázar increasingly risky. Many of its inhabitants have emigrated, but many remain. In more than one occasion the central government has spoken of moving the town somewhere else, but no concrete relocation plans have been proposed. Due to this constant uncertainty, property prices have fallen drastically, and some of the town’s buildings, while in good conditions, cannot be used because of their location in “high-risk areas.” Business and construction have taken a hard hit, leaving many out of their jobs.
